awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2022: Innate immunity could buffer extinction risk in genetically compromised populations
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes.  The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways.  The long term survival of a species is thought to be associated with the genetic diversity of that species. In fact, current conservation efforts for endangered and threatened species work to maintain genetic diversity within populations in the hopes of increasing their chances for long term survival.  However, recent studies have challenged this idea.  The fellow seeks to understand how the loss of genetic diversity affects the survival of a species by focusing on the immune system, which allows organisms to fight off disease. The immune system can be viewed as a complex system that may shield against losses of diversity at specific genes. The work generated here will contribute to the understanding of how threatened and endangered species persist in the face of a rapidly changing environment and will help clarify genetic management plans aimed at their recovery.

The fellow will answer the proposed questions through bioinformatic and lab experiments focused on Gila trout, (Oncorhynchus gilae), a threatened fish species that has undergone numerous events leading to significant loss of genetic diversity within its populations.  Diversity loss has impacted the major histocompatibility locus of the Gila trout, potentially reducing its ability to respond to pathogens via classical adaptive immune responses. The fellow will use the Gila trout genome, tissue archives, and gene sequence libraries to identify, annotate, and evaluate the diversity of innate immune gene families to understand if innate immunity may compensate for reduced adaptive immune capabilities. This will also establish how these immune genes are evolving, and the effects of selection acting upon them.  Immune challenge experiments will quantify the magnitude of the overall immune response in Gila trout and the role of innate immune receptors in this species during infection.  These two approaches will determine whether overall genetic loss can be compensated via expansion of broadly unspecific arms of the immune system and allow long-term persistence.  The fellow will also perform multiple outreach projects including presentations on the importance of habitat conservation, leading undergraduates in museum science programs, and presenting the results of the fellow’s research to relevant conservation agencies.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to generate a genome and characterize the immune genes and their expression in the Gila trout, a threatened native New Mexican trout species found in the Gila National Forest. Genetic resources are needed given the threatened nature of this species and previous data indicating a loss in genetic variation within the species. Over the course of two years a Gila trout genome was generated from DNA collected from two Gila trout received from the Museum of Southwest biology. This genome was annotated using data from a closely related trout species, the Rainbow trout, and will be released for public access upon full publication of results. To date the genome has been made available to U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Southwestern Native Aquatic Resources and Recovery Center for their use in furthering Gila Trout conservation efforts. Immune genes of interest thought to play key roles in protection against pathogens and disease, were specifically identified and annotated within the genome. They were further analyzed against the same genes found within other closely related fish species. These species included other trout and salmon. It was found that most of these genes were highly conserved across fish species, but that regions of variability could still be identified within the non-coding regions of these genes. Further analysis of the TLRs, a family of immune genes known for their diverse binding properties against a number of pathogens, were selected for deeper analysis.  Sixteen TLRs were identified within the Gila trout genome along with two pseudo genes. TLR1 was further studied across multiple Gila trout individuals in an attempt to determine population dynamics for this gene and to see in genetic variation could be found. Data indicated that this gene showed a similar reduced genetic variation as seen previously in the Gila trout populations. β-defensins, a set of small immune genes with antimicrobial properties, were also studied. These immune genes were found to be highly conserved across the trout and salmon species studied here indicating that they may be particularly important to these fish as they have been maintained. Immune challenge experiments were also conducted on a set of Gila trout received from the Mora Fish Hatchery, New Mexico. These trout were vaccinated against enteric red mouth (ERM) disease and were subsequently sampled at 6, 24, and 48 hours post vaccination, and RNA was extracted form gills, guts, spleen, head kidney, and skin. The expression of four β-defensins – bd-1a, bd-1b, bd-3, bd-4 – were analyzed from skin samples. It was found that β-defensins were not upregulated upon vaccination but that expression levels were already high in Gila trout skin indicating that they might already be readily active in the skin. In addition to gene expression, serum was taken from fish at 6 weeks post vaccination and anti-body (specifically IgM) levels were analyzed. While only half of the vaccinated fish showed a significant change in IgM levels, the difference between the ones that did, and the unvaccinated controls was significant.

Outreach activities for this fellowship consisted of visiting local elementary schools to teach students about the local fish species. This lesson involved introducing students, grades K-2, to the concepts of habitats, food chains, and used Realia from the Museum of Southwestern Biology to allow students hands-on interaction with the species covered in the presentation. In addition to this outreach course, a university level journal reading course on ‘Reading in STEM DEI’ led by Drs. Michael Anderson, Irene Salinas, and Megan Barela Hudgell was offered. Lastly, the genomic data was made available for the management and conservation of the Gila Trout. This was done through the production of a Gila Trout genome along with tissue samples from vaccinated fish which were collected and given to the Museum of Southwestern Biology for their collections.
